source.raw_text:
Prone Y-Raises primarily target the lower trapezius, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, strengthening the upper back for posture and shoulder stability, while also engaging the rotator cuff (infraspinatus, teres minor, supraspinatus) and serratus anterior. The movement pattern involves lying face-down and lifting straight arms at a 45-degree angle from the torso (forming a "Y"), focusing on squeezing the shoulder blades down and back, and initiating the lift from the scapula for scapular control. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers: Lower Trapezius, Rhomboids (major & minor) 
• Shoulder Stabilizers/Synergists: Rear Deltoids, Serratus Anterior, Rotator Cuff (Supraspinatus, Infraspinatus, Teres Minor) 
• Core: Engaged for stabilization [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]  

Movement Pattern & Key Cues 

1. Starting Position: Lie face down (prone) on a mat or bench, forehead supported (e.g., on a rolled towel). Extend arms at roughly 45 degrees from your body (like a "Y"), palms facing down or thumbs up. 
2. Initiation: Engage your core and glutes. Squeeze your shoulder blades down and back (depression and retraction). 
3. The Lift: Lift your arms by contracting your mid-back, keeping arms straight (slight bend in elbow is okay) and neck neutral. 
4. End Range: Reach towards the ceiling, holding briefly at the top to feel the contraction in your upper back. 
5. Controlled Lowering: Slowly lower arms back down with control, resisting gravity. [1, 4, 7]  

Benefits 

• Improves Posture: Balances out forward-pulling chest muscles. 
• Enhances Shoulder Stability: Strengthens muscles crucial for pain-free overhead movement. 
• Rehabilitative: Excellent for shoulder injuries and conditions like winged scapula. [1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 8]  

**Citations:**
